doc.title: BAMBE

description.text: Bayesian Analysis in Molecular Biology and Evolution

doc.reference: Larget, B. and D. Simon (1999). Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms for the Bayesian analysis of phylogenetic trees. Molecular Biology and Evolution 16:750-759.
Simon, D. and B. Larget. 1998. Bayesian analysis in molecular biology and evolution (BAMBE), version 1.01 beta. Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Duquesne University.

xhtml:div.label: Seed for random number generator (seed)
Number of cycles to run the main algorithm (cycles)

Number of cycles between printing trees to output (window-interval)?
Also used for updating the window size during burn-in.
Algorithm to run during production cycles (main-algorithm) Global Local

Number of cycles to run the burn algorithm (burn)?
Parameter values are not updated during burn. User should discard these cycles and the initial cycles of the main algorithm before inference.
Algorithm to run during burn (burn-algorithm) Global Local
Use scaled beta distribution modification of the local algorithm (use-beta) Yes No
Use a molecular clock (molecular-clock) Yes No
Likelihood model (likelihood-model) Hasegawa, Kishino, Yano (HKY85) Felsenstein's PHYLIP (F84) Tamura-Nei (TN93) Hayley (GREV)

A valid category list (category-list)?
Each category has its own set of parameters. Each category is denoted by a positive integer between 1 and 10. A comma-separated list gives the categories of the sites in order, e.g., 1,2,3,1,3 means that the first site is in category 1, the second in 2, the third in 3, the fourth in 1, and the fifth site is in category 3.
A repeat count is indicated by a caret (^). For example, 1^20,2^5,3^2 means that the first twenty sites are in category 1, the next five sites are in 2, and the next two sites are in category 3.
Parentheses may be used to group sites together with a common repeat count, i.e., (1,2)^5 is the same as 1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2. Repeat counts may be nested, e.g., (1^3,2)^2 is the same as 1,1,1,2,1,1,1,2.
Repetition to the end of the list of sites is indicated by an asterisk (*). For example, 1^5,2* means that the first five sites are in category 1, and all the remaining sites are in category 2. Parentheses may also be used in conjunction with the asterisk, e.g., (1,2)* is the same as 1,2,1,2,1,2,.... The category list may contain at most one asterisk and it must be associated with the last category or group in the list. In other words, an asterisk may appear only at the end of the list.
Examples
1* - all sites are the same category. (default)
(1,2,3)* - all sites are partitioned by codon position.
1^99,2^50,3^9 - the sites are divided over three genes. Each gene has its own set of parameters used by all sites in that gene. The first gene is composed of the first ninety-nine sites, the next by the next fifty sites, and the last by nine sites.

Single kappa (single-kappa)?
Yes No
If true, the same kappa parameter is used for all site categories. If false, there are different values for different site categories. It has no effect if there is only one rate category.

Comma separated list of positive kappa values for each site category (initial-kappa)?
If single-kappa is true, a warning is given if more than one value is specified. The first value will be used. If single-kappa is false, a value must be specified for each category in use.

Comma separated list of positive theta values for each site category (initial-theta)?
The weighted average of these values should be 1, with weights given by the proportion of sites in each site category. (Renormalization is automatic and a warning given if the condition fails.) If there are an equal number of sites in each category, for example, the numbers should average to 1.

Use empirical relative frequencies (estimate-pi)?
Yes No
If true, the initial stationary probabilities for each base in each category are estimated by the relative frequencies with which they appear in the data.
Comma separated list of initial pi value of base A (initial-pia)
Comma separated list of initial pi value of base G (initial-pig)
Comma separated list of initial pi value of base C (initial-pic)
Comma separated list of initial pi value of base T (initial-pit)

Comma separated list of positive transition/transversion parameter values (TN93 model) (initial-ttp)?
This is used only with TN93. There must be a value specified for each site-category used if TN93 is the chosen model.

Comma separated list of positive gamma values (TN93 model) (initial-gamma)?
This is used only with TN93. There must be a value specified for each site-category used if TN93 is the chosen model.

Comma separated list of positive r values for AC bases(GREV model) (initial-rac)?
This is used only with GREV model.

Comma separated list of positive r values for AG (GREV model) (initial-rag)?
This is used only with GREV model.

Comma separated list of positive r values for AT (GREV model) (initial-rat)?
This is used only with GREV model.

Comma separated list of positive r values for CG (GREV model) (initial-rcg)?
This is used only with GREV model.

Comma separated list of positive r values for CT (GREV model) (initial-rct)?
This is used only with GREV model.

Comma separated list of positive r values for GT (GREV model) (initial-rct)?
This is used only with GREV model.

Parameter update interval (parameter-update-interval)?
During the main algorithm, any 'on' parameters are updated at each cycle divisible by this value. Use zero for no parameter updating.
Update kappa value (update-kappa) Yes No
Update theta value (update-theta) Yes No
Update pi value (update-pi) Yes No
Update ttp value (TN93 model) (update-ttp) Yes No
Update gamma value for (TN93 model) (update-gamma) Yes No
Update grev (GREV model) (update-grev) Yes No
Update invariant probability (update-invariant-prob) Yes No

Stretch parameter for local (local-tune)?
This tuning parameter is only used with the local algorithm. It modulates the size of a maximal stretch. The smaller the value, the greater the tree acceptance rate will be.

Dirichlet parameter for theta update (theta-tune)?
Tuning parameter used during update of theta value(s). The larger its value, the more likely proposals are to be accepted.

Dirichlet parameter for pi update (pi-tune)?
Tuning parameter used during update of pi values. The larger its value, the more likely proposals are to be accepted.

Halft the size of the window for uniform updates of kappa (kappa-tune)?
This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-kappa' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

Halft window width for ttp update (TN93 model) (ttp-tune)?
This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-ttp' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

Half window width for gamma update (TN93 model) (gamma-tune)?
This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-gamma' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.
Halft window width for grev update (grev-tune)
Beta parameter for local update (beta-tune)
Halft window width for invariant probability update (invariant-prob-tune)

Sample interval (sample-interval)?
During burn and main algorithms, the tree topology, log likelihoods, and parameters are written to files at each cycle divisible by this value.

Newick format of tree file (newick-format)?
Yes No
Indicates the format of the tree to read (if not random) and the format of the tree to print after the run.

Number of the outgroup (outgroup)?
This is ignored if a molecular clock is assumed. In the absence of a clock, trees and tree topologies are printed with the outgroup emerging directly from the root.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If no tree file is given, the program generates a random tree from a flat distribution where each labeled history is equally likely.

xhtml:div.label:
Initial tree type (initial-tree-type)?
Random UPGMA Neighbor-Joining Newick Bambe
. random select a tree from the prior
. upgma sets the initial clock tree to the UPGMA tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. neighbor-joining sets the initial nonclock tree to the neigbor joining tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. newick reads in an initial tree in Newick format from a file.
. bambe reads in an initial tree in BAMBE format from a file.
Print all trees?(print-all-trees) Yes No

Initial tree height used to generate an initial random tree (max-initial-tree-height)?
This parameter is only used to generate an initial random tree.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Also used for updating the window size during burn-in.
Parameter values are not updated during burn. User should discard these cycles and the initial cycles of the main algorithm before inference.

Each category has its own set of parameters. Each category is denoted by a positive integer between 1 and 10. A comma-separated list gives the categories of the sites in order, e.g., 1,2,3,1,3 means that the first site is in category 1, the second in 2, the third in 3, the fourth in 1, and the fifth site is in category 3.
A repeat count is indicated by a caret (^). For example, 1^20,2^5,3^2 means that the first twenty sites are in category 1, the next five sites are in 2, and the next two sites are in category 3.

Parentheses may be used to group sites together with a common repeat count, i.e., (1,2)^5 is the same as 1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2. Repeat counts may be nested, e.g., (1^3,2)^2 is the same as 1,1,1,2,1,1,1,2.

Repetition to the end of the list of sites is indicated by an asterisk (*). For example, 1^5,2* means that the first five sites are in category 1, and all the remaining sites are in category 2. Parentheses may also be used in conjunction with the asterisk, e.g., (1,2)* is the same as 1,2,1,2,1,2,.... The category list may contain at most one asterisk and it must be associated with the last category or group in the list. In other words, an asterisk may appear only at the end of the list.
Examples
1* - all sites are the same category. (default)
(1,2,3)* - all sites are partitioned by codon position.

1^99,2^50,3^9 - the sites are divided over three genes. Each gene has its own set of parameters used by all sites in that gene. The first gene is composed of the first ninety-nine sites, the next by the next fifty sites, and the last by nine sites.
If true, the same kappa parameter is used for all site categories. If false, there are different values for different site categories. It has no effect if there is only one rate category.
If single-kappa is true, a warning is given if more than one value is specified. The first value will be used. If single-kappa is false, a value must be specified for each category in use.

The weighted average of these values should be 1, with weights given by the proportion of sites in each site category. (Renormalization is automatic and a warning given if the condition fails.) If there are an equal number of sites in each category, for example, the numbers should average to 1.
If true, the initial stationary probabilities for each base in each category are estimated by the relative frequencies with which they appear in the data.
This is used only with TN93. There must be a value specified for each site-category used if TN93 is the chosen model.
This is used only with TN93. There must be a value specified for each site-category used if TN93 is the chosen model.
This is used only with GREV model.
This is used only with GREV model.

During the main algorithm, any 'on' parameters are updated at each cycle divisible by this value. Use zero for no parameter updating.
This tuning parameter is only used with the local algorithm. It modulates the size of a maximal stretch. The smaller the value, the greater the tree acceptance rate will be.
Tuning parameter used during update of theta value(s). The larger its value, the more likely proposals are to be accepted.
Tuning parameter used during update of pi values. The larger its value, the more likely proposals are to be accepted.
This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-kappa' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

During burn and main algorithms, the tree topology, log likelihoods, and parameters are written to files at each cycle divisible by this value.
Indicates the format of the tree to read (if not random) and the format of the tree to print after the run.
This is ignored if a molecular clock is assumed. In the absence of a clock, trees and tree topologies are printed with the outgroup emerging directly from the root.
If no tree file is given, the program generates a random tree from a flat distribution where each labeled history is equally likely.
. random select a tree from the prior
. upgma sets the initial clock tree to the UPGMA tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. neighbor-joining sets the initial nonclock tree to the neigbor joining tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. newick reads in an initial tree in Newick format from a file.
. bambe reads in an initial tree in BAMBE format from a file.

comment.text: Each category has its own set of parameters. Each category is denoted by a positive integer between 1 and 10. A comma-separated list gives the categories of the sites in order, e.g., 1,2,3,1,3 means that the first site is in category 1, the second in 2, the third in 3, the fourth in 1, and the fifth site is in category 3.
A repeat count is indicated by a caret (^). For example, 1^20,2^5,3^2 means that the first twenty sites are in category 1, the next five sites are in 2, and the next two sites are in category 3.

Parentheses may be used to group sites together with a common repeat count, i.e., (1,2)^5 is the same as 1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2,1,2. Repeat counts may be nested, e.g., (1^3,2)^2 is the same as 1,1,1,2,1,1,1,2.

Repetition to the end of the list of sites is indicated by an asterisk (*). For example, 1^5,2* means that the first five sites are in category 1, and all the remaining sites are in category 2. Parentheses may also be used in conjunction with the asterisk, e.g., (1,2)* is the same as 1,2,1,2,1,2,.... The category list may contain at most one asterisk and it must be associated with the last category or group in the list. In other words, an asterisk may appear only at the end of the list.

1^99,2^50,3^9 - the sites are divided over three genes. Each gene has its own set of parameters used by all sites in that gene. The first gene is composed of the first ninety-nine sites, the next by the next fifty sites, and the last by nine sites.

parameter.name: kappa_tune
parameter.prompt: Halft the size of the window for uniform updates of kappa (kappa-tune)

precond.code: parameter_update_interval != 0 and update_kappa and (likelihood_model == "HKY85" or likelihood_model == "F84")

comment.text: This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-kappa' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

interface.label:
Halft the size of the window for uniform updates of kappa (kappa-tune)?
This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-kappa' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-kappa' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

parameter.name: ttp_tune
parameter.prompt: Halft window width for ttp update (TN93 model) (ttp-tune)

comment.text: This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-ttp' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

interface.label:
Halft window width for ttp update (TN93 model) (ttp-tune)?
This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-ttp' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-ttp' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

parameter.name: gamma_tune
parameter.prompt: Half window width for gamma update (TN93 model) (gamma-tune)

comment.text: This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-gamma' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

interface.label:
Half window width for gamma update (TN93 model) (gamma-tune)?
This tuning parameter is only used when 'parameter-update-interval' is positive and 'update-gamma' is true. The smaller its value, the greater the parameter acceptance rate will be.

parameter.name: grev_tune

parameter.name: invariant_prob_tune
parameter.prompt: Halft window width for invariant probability update (invariant-prob-tune)

comment.text: During burn and main algorithms, the tree topology, log likelihoods, and parameters are written to files at each cycle divisible by this value.

interface.label:
Sample interval (sample-interval)?
During burn and main algorithms, the tree topology, log likelihoods, and parameters are written to files at each cycle divisible by this value.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: During burn and main algorithms, the tree topology, log likelihoods, and parameters are written to files at each cycle divisible by this value.

comment.text: Indicates the format of the tree to read (if not random) and the format of the tree to print after the run.

interface.label:
Newick format of tree file (newick-format)?
Yes No
Indicates the format of the tree to read (if not random) and the format of the tree to print after the run.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Indicates the format of the tree to read (if not random) and the format of the tree to print after the run.

comment.text: This is ignored if a molecular clock is assumed. In the absence of a clock, trees and tree topologies are printed with the outgroup emerging directly from the root.

interface.label:
Number of the outgroup (outgroup)?
This is ignored if a molecular clock is assumed. In the absence of a clock, trees and tree topologies are printed with the outgroup emerging directly from the root.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This is ignored if a molecular clock is assumed. In the absence of a clock, trees and tree topologies are printed with the outgroup emerging directly from the root.

comment.text: If no tree file is given, the program generates a random tree from a flat distribution where each labeled history is equally likely.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If no tree file is given, the program generates a random tree from a flat distribution where each labeled history is equally likely.

format.code: ("", "initial-tree-type="+str(value)+"\n")[value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: . random select a tree from the prior
. upgma sets the initial clock tree to the UPGMA tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. neighbor-joining sets the initial nonclock tree to the neigbor joining tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. newick reads in an initial tree in Newick format from a file.
. bambe reads in an initial tree in BAMBE format from a file.

interface.label:
Initial tree type (initial-tree-type)?
Random UPGMA Neighbor-Joining Newick Bambe
. random select a tree from the prior
. upgma sets the initial clock tree to the UPGMA tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. neighbor-joining sets the initial nonclock tree to the neigbor joining tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. newick reads in an initial tree in Newick format from a file.
. bambe reads in an initial tree in BAMBE format from a file.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: . random select a tree from the prior
. upgma sets the initial clock tree to the UPGMA tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. neighbor-joining sets the initial nonclock tree to the neigbor joining tree using maximum likelihood distances with the specified model and initial parameter values.
. newick reads in an initial tree in Newick format from a file.
. bambe reads in an initial tree in BAMBE format from a file.

interface.label: Print all trees?(print-all-trees) Yes No

parameter.name: max_initial_tree_height

comment.text: This parameter is only used to generate an initial random tree.
